argumentText:
Let $\alpha$ be the angle between the sides $b$ and $c$, then we get
from the cosines law: $$\cos\alpha =\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}.$$ Using the
equation $$\sin\alpha=\sqrt{1-\cos^2\alpha}$$ we get:
$$\sin\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{-a^4-b^4-c^4+2b^2c^2+2a^2b^2+2a^2c^2}}{2bc}.$$
Now we know: $$\Delta=\frac{1}{2}bc\sin\alpha.$$ So we get:
$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta & = & \frac{1}{4}\sqrt{-a^4-b^4-c^4+2b^2c^2+2a^2b^2+2a^2c^2}\\
& = & \frac{1}{4}\sqrt{(a+b+c)(b+c-a)(a+c-b)(a+b-c)}\\
& = & \sqrt{s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)}.\end{aligned}$$ This is Heron’s formula.
$\Box$
